author: Rajiv Tangri
title: Incentivized Participation
description: How do we achieve greater involvement at multiple levels.

assessments.note:
Although it is possible to glimpse the proposer's idea, the problem statement doesn't describe a problem and the description of the solution is not clear. This information is essential for the proposal to be able to clearly communicate its intention to the community and increase the chances of success in the vote. The plan described is a draft, it needs to be better detailed. Improving the communication of important events is an important aspect, but it is not clear how it will have a relevant impact on the challenge.

It is essential that the proposal communicates more clearly what the objective is and how that objective is related to the challenge.

While incentivizing participation is a good idea, a model like this might most likely attract many people just grinding for the rewards that are not really interested in the projects. The amount of work and costs for programming a new app and cryptocurrency does not justify compared to the small amount allocated to the rewards and the effect they will have. I encourage the proposer to refine the idea for the next funding round.

The reward mechanism for participation in Catalysts is already present. The catalyst voting app can be also be configured to send notifications. A separate app for reminding stakeholders is likely to a unsustainable solution.

The idea of reminders to increase the participation in Catalyst is great, but I believe that the proposal budget is somewhat unbalanced. 90% of it would go the developer and 10% only for rewards distribution. This amount would also give very low incentives to all participants, and would probably have a low impact. I believe 50/50 would be a fairer split and could increase the proposals impact. Some more information about the kinds of interactions that would be rewarded should be included in the text as well to support a better understanding of it.
It could be an interesting way incentivise participation. More thought needs to go into the tokenomics, fees involved and ongoing funding model

The proposal has good intentions but doesn't relate it to Catalyst in a clear way. more details are needed. How would the proposed tokens be valuable (DANO?)?
Where would the ADA come from? Also, a centralized server based app which tracks user activity would be a hard sell in the community.

The proposer did not describe experiences relevant to the proposal. For the development of an app, a developer (who would be hired) would be needed.

There is no reasonable plan and there is no clarity in the purpose of the proposal. Some ideas are mentioned, like the distribution of funds for people to read proposals and comment on them, but how will this be accomplished? Creating financial incentives for comments and reading inserts vulnerabilities where people can exploit the system through fake accounts or bots. There is no mention of this problem or how to mitigate it. There is also mention of a voting app, but voting for what? Proposals? We already have a voting app for Catalyst proposals and soon this will be done by official portfolios, so what is the purpose of a voting app? There is mention of allowing video conferences in the app, but how does this relate to the challenge?

I recommend clarifying the points mentioned above and that the proposer follow the Catalyst documentation to write the proposal, addressing the points.

Finally, the proposer completed the self assessment checklist, but clearly the proposal lacks details.
The assessed budget is not at all enough to develop an app and a new crypto token. No rationale is provided for that extremely optimistic cost calculation.

The proposer needs to hire a developer for making app and the does not claim prior experience in software development or management. There estimate for cost for secure online chat app is very optimistic.

The proposer relevant experience is the knowledge of similar applications in other areas that served as inspiration for this idea. Although, there is no dev in the team yet, and the dev would be hired only 3 months after the fund is released, which seems a long time for this step only. It also aims to increase involvement in 10 times, but it seems unfeasible with the amount of rewards that would be distributed.
Proposer is not technical thus needs to hire someone to do it. Without a solid plan unlikely it will be implemented successfully on budget

The proposer doesn't have any relevant experience with the technology stack required to accurately scope the work needed to achieve the goals presented. the problem statement doesn't identify a problem, it could be clarified with some more data which shows low involvement / participation.

The proposal is a draft and lacks many details to allow auditability. There is no clarity on how the proposal will address the challenge, there is no concrete plan / roadmap / milestones / metrics / KPIs. There are no details on the budget allocation (a budget of 9000USD was defined to hire a developer, what were the references for setting the budget? Is there a rationale or number of hours of work to justify this amount?).

Which references were used to define the established goals?

I recommend that the proposal be detailed and follow the Catalyst documentation so that we can provide appropriate feedback.

While the general idea to incentivize participation is good, many questions on the exact development plan and the specific mechanisms and role of the crypto token are left unanswered. Simple reminders would not need something as complex as an app. If re-proposed. this project needs more detailed schematics in order to be deemed feasible
The development of the proposed app is likely to be feasible however the app with chat and notification along with the reward for participation may not be addressing the value onboarding issue.

An overview of a plan was stated, and the KPI proposed is a single one based on the increase of involvement of the community, which is not clear about how it would be measured. Some challenges regarding how to assess each one's participation and calculate it's rewards was not discussed and this would be very important for the proposal's accountability and transparency.

There is not actual plan for the technical build. This is an idea that needs more detail. Where will future funding come from. If this involves thousands of micro payments how will the transaction fees on those be paid?

The proposal provides a small amount of unclear milestones, which don't relate to achieving the stated goal in a measurable and auditable way. simply publishing an app isn't sufficient. A 1000% increase in involvement doesn't show an absolute change in participation, what was the baseline?
